Time handed in and Official Instructions—if any. CIRCUIT CLERK’S NAME TIME RECEIVED AN. PEARS. 2130 / 18 . h at d ISSUING OFFICE © l t8D Ecmo:~) • wo As VM14 S BAHRAIN 9/8 l8 1849 OBGS WITH PTY POLITICAL MUSCAT = n s- J 7 21418 YOURTEL 17P VISIT CANCELLED = HAY = If.;. 5 2-^0 Enquiry respecting this telegram should be accompanied by this form and may be made at any of the Company’s offices41/9/1-A/50. H.B.H's Consulate and Political Agency, MUSCAT* 12th Deceid&er, 1950* Yy dear Pinhey I eiidose a draft programme, with three spare copies. which, if approved, nay kindly he forwarded to the Senior Naval Officer, Persian Gulf with reference to his letter No.P.G./ 135/ /50/1 dated the 15th November 1950. The next mail will be the 21st and if it is decided to go on with the Congnander-inrChief * s visit to Mbsoat after all, it would be too late to send it by post then* 2. The programme i s c f course prepared on the aswumptic*i that the Sultan will not be here* It would not be hard to adjust if he did come* It is not very attractive from the visitors view point, but the colony so small and amenities next to nil, as they already know I fear. Yours sincerely L.A.G. Pinhey EBq* 0.B.E* First Secretary, The British Residency, BAHRAIN*I Personal, H.B.M’s Consulate and I^olitical Agency, MUSCAT> 3rd Decernber, 1950* 'y dear Sir Rupert, TViank you very anucn for your kind letter of the 28th brought by Boe worth* Tq ’Tent out at noon, to the airfield to meet him and the Parkers, as that was the E.T.A. we had received, but they had not arrived by 1*15 P*®. and as we had a luncheon engagement we could not wait* Finally they arrived at 2.30 p.m. and went off almost at once, so we missed them* I should have liked to put them tip had they been able to stay. V/e have f&ready written for Christmas things here and there, and if they turn up then we should do well* It is extra ordinary how quickly this festival seems to come round J We shall very greatly look forward to your visit, and the dates you mention will, of course, suit us* I hope your youngest deugjitar will also be coming. I have asked Woods-Ballard to cable the Sultan for a definite reply, but so far ro response. I shall forward it on as soon as it comes. Perhaps your enquiries have been more successful. I cannot think vmy the Suit an is so reluctant to give a date, but it is probably that he Just does not want to decide while he has a number of things on his hards in Phofar, and while the weather is so fine: though it is really lovely here new, and it seems November and early December is the time for Naval visits, if they want easy conditions for boat wen:. ours sincerely. His Excellency Sir Rupert Hay, K.C.I.E. ,C.S.I, Political Resident in the Persian Gulf. BAHRAIN* MC.BRITISH RESIDFNCY, BAHRAIN. 28th November, I960 My dear Friend, This is to inform Your Highness that Admiral Oliver, Commander-in-Chief, T ast Indies, desires, if convenient, to visit Muscat in H.M.S. 'Mauritius” from the 8th to the 11th January. Would Your Highness very kindly let me know if you expect to be in Muscat r at that time and if the dates will be convenient to you ? Major Chauncy has already been asked to inform Your Highness on the above lines through the proper authority at Muscat, but as it is possible that the information may not have reached you yet, and I have now this opportunity of speedy communication with you, I have thought it best to write to Your Highness direct, and I shall be very grateful if your Highness would kindly let me know what I should say to the Admiral on the subject. V.ith best wishes and kindest regards, 1 am, Yours very sincerely, His Highness Saiyid Said bin Taimur, Sultan of Muscat and Oman.Printed in England April 1948. (5000pads) 1®*A Telegram rT R’ T From To Date s ent Political ’'us cat ‘ ’rodrorne Bahrain 11th December 1950 . No. 1?2. Your telegram No. 212 dated the 9^ December. I have ascertained that no offence will he taken at the omission of Nuscat from the programme of the Commander- in-chiefs cruise this year in t 1 e circumstances. Please inform Senior Naval Officer Persian Gulf and let me know- final decision. CHAUNCY.\ No. 221 /20-Mi sc SULTANATE OF MUSCAT & OMAN MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS MUSCAT 10th. Dacember 1950. VISIT OF H.U.S. MAURITIUS 1951. ry Thank you for your letter No.35/9/l-A/50» dated the 10th. December 1950. 2. It is confirmed that, as it is not certain that the Sultan will be back by the 8th. of January, should the Goramander-in-Chief omit his visit to Muscat from his tour this time that no offence will be taken, even if, after all, the Sultan ultimately decides to return to Muscat earlier as it would not be possible to adjust the programme at a later date. Major F. C. L. Chauncy, His Britannic Majesty*s Consul MUSCAT, MA, III 7 '9th December, 1950 VISIT H. S. MAURITIUS 1951 Please refer to your letter No. 33/9/1-A/50, dated the 9th December, 1950. The draft programme seems very suitable to me. I think you are right in assuming the Sultan will not have returned by that time but if he is back, as you rill be quite easy suitably to adjust the programme. 3* # About the suggested small dinner party for me on the first day- again I agree with you it is better to let them know in advance and it will probably make things easier for us. 4. . Please let me know if you wAuld like the Pontiac and Jeep at any time. 11 Major P. 0. L. Chauncy, His Britannic Majesty’s Consul, Muscat. WGnmmmmmmmmMmmmmmmmmmmmmm33/9/1-A/50 Consulate, MyggAT. 9th December, 1950* }y dear 7oods-Ballard, X enclose & copy of a draft programme for the Commandep-inrChlef' s visit and shall be grateful to know whether you consider it suitable, I shall be obliged if you can let me know before the next mail leaves for Bahrain. 2* I have suggested a small dinner party for you on the first day, after all, as I feel it would be as well to let them know in advance, and I don*t think you shoiild be landed for anything bigger in the circumstances we discussed* 3* I have assumed that the Sultan will not be there, but it will be easy to adjust if he is. V* Of course this is only a draft and the final programme still requires suggestions from the Mauritius and approval of all concerned. Yours sincerely. F* Woods-Ballard Esq, C.I.E., H.B.E. minister for foreign Affairs, MUSCAT.Telegram R Prom 'Prodrome Bahrain To Political luscat Date sent 8th December - Date received 9th December. Fo. 212. 4 Restricted. ''ollo'.dn, from Senior Naval Officer, ^ersian Gulf. Commander-in-Chief, Bast I dies on learning that ultan may not be back by the 8th January states that his natural reaction is to cancel visit. Political Resident in the Persian Gulf agrees subject to confirmation by you that no offence will be taken. 2. Grateful for an early reply. 8. Decision made now must stand whatever Sultan’s eventual movements may be.URGEHT AND COMFIEEHTIAL. 3I/9/1-A/50. H.B.M's Comsulate and Political Ageacy, Muscat December 5th, 1950. Visit of ComTna*der-i*-Chlef. Uy dear Finhey Please refer to connected correspondence, and in particular the Political Residents telegram stating that we cannot allow the Comraander-in- Chief to arrive and find the Sultan not here. Unless the Sultan has informed Sir Rupert in a letter just received and forwarded by this bag, the only information we can obtain in^pite of specific telegraphic enquiry is contained in the enclosed official reply from Woods-Ballard, which may kindly be passed on to the Senior Naval Officer and the Commander-in-Chief. I have been asked by the Senior Naval Officer in the Persian Gulf to forward a draft programme. If there is a^y likelihood of the Mauritius not visiting Muscat in the circumstances, I shall be grateful to know as soon as possible. In the meantime I can only prepare a programme as for when the Sultan is away. Except for the size of the salute, and a lunch to the Sultan, there will be little difference. The Sultans representative does not attend social functions. Yours sincerely, L.A.G. Pinhey, Esquire, O.B.E., First Secretary, The British Residency, Bahrain■■■■■■■■■■■■■ SULTANATE OF MUSCAT & OMAN No. /20-Misc. MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS MUSCAT 5th December, 1950. Sir, I have the honour to refer to your letter No. 28/9/1-A/50,dated the 29th November 1950 and to say that the Muscat Government welcome the proposed visit' of His Excellency the Commander In Chief in H. M. S Mauritius from the 8th to the 11th January 1951. The dates are quite convenient but it is possible that the Sultan may not be here at that time. I have the honour to be, Sir, Your obedient servant, Minister for For< ff Sirs. His Britannic Majesty’s Consul, Muscat. (Mahbub) O' (K 1^* vtexetJ?Personal, H.B.M’s Consulate, MUSCAT , 1st December, 1950, ] 'y dear .Toods-Eallard, With reference to nor letter about the proposal that H.K.S, Mauritius should visit >Aiscat frcm the 8th to 11th January 1951, it will be much appreciated if definite information could be supplied at an early date as to whether the Sultan will or will not be at Muscat during the dates indicated, j.f you see no objection, therefore, could you very kindly ascertain this much by cable, without it appearing that we are being importunate. Yours sincerely, K- B. Woods-Ballard Esq, C.I.E. ,M.B.K. Minister for Foreign Affairs, MUSCAT.Telegram 'R' From ' Prodrome Bahrain To Political buscat Date sent 28th ~ovember, Da- No. 199. 5 ,V’ Confidential, Your letter No, 25/9/1/50 of the 20th November. Ye cannot let Comrander-in-Chief arrive Muscat and find that 3ultan is not there. Please do your best to obtain a definite reply whether' he will or will not be present during dates indicated. *28/9/1-a/50 Ii»B»M*s Consulate, rg3QA!T. 29th IJowerior, 1950. i±r p I have the honour to :‘nfonn you that Ids xoellc-ncry- the Goiiinandei>*in*Ohief in Ii*K*S« l^uritius would like to visit ?tec5©t fron the 8th to 11th January 1951* to enquire whether this will be convenient to His Jdghness the Sultan* I have the honour to be ;.ir. Your obedient servant* r Is Britannic “aiesty's Consul, ^jsofet* Mrdster for foreign Affairs, , Sultanate of ?\isoat & Orion, YUSSAiT *IConfidential, 25757V50. s Consulate and Political Agency, MUSCAT . 20th November, 1950# U-2v l*y dear Sir Rupert, Q\ fy Please refer to your telegram No. 191 dated the 16th November 1950. 2* ,/oods-Ballard can only say that 'signs' are that there is a fair chance of the Sultan coming to Muscat at the end of December. 3. With regard to the choice of dates for the Comaander-in-Cbief’s proposed visit, 3th to 11th January, the dates for the Indian Navy’s possible visit are given as 7th / . / to 9th January. It seems that they should not clash. K. I do not think that enquiry direct from the Sultan wiljL elicit any response other than that he has not yet decided, andjif we mention the naval visits as a reason for pressing for a reply he might quite possibly 'welcome' the dates suggested, and make sure he does not get back for them. last year he nearly cleared off to Sur during the Comnander-in-Chief's visit, and though he may not mind war ships visiting ]Muscat, I am sure he dislikes the 'drill', or in fact anything that the even tejfor 0 f his life. Yours sincerely. 3d/- F. C.L. Chauncy. His Excellency Sir Rupert Hay, K.C.I.E., Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, BAHRAIN. MC.Telegram 'R' From Prodrome, Bahrain To Political, liuscat Pate sent & received “16th November 1950. No. 191 x PRIORITY. Confidential. 'Te have been told unoficially that present programme is that Commander-in-Chief Bast Indies in H.M.S. Jauritius will probably visit liiscat January 8th to January 11th before proceeding to Bahrain. Can you obtain any definite information about Sultan’s return. HAY, /! >■ { 4 O-'/h So ■r-S f 7 Office th^ Senior Naval Officer, Poraiar Oulf, 19th August, 19504 No. P.G. 1A/105/50. NXS BRITANNIC l!AJSSTY’S AMBASSADOR, TEHRAN. I IS bRITANNIC MAJESTY’S AMBASSADOR , BAGDAD. TI T E POLITICAL RESIDENT PERSIAN CULP# TFE POLITICAL A CENT, BAHRAIN. THE POLITICAL AGENT, KUWAIT. Pis BRITANNIC MAJESTY’S CONSUL GENERAL, ^SRA. FIS ^RITANNIC MAJESTY’S CONSUL GENERAL, KPORRAMS/A TT'E POL ITICAL MUSCAT* w* Political officer, trucial coast, WX POLITICAL OFFICER, QATAR. FIS ^RITANNIC MAJESTY’S VICE CONSUL, bUSFXRE. AIR OFFICER COMMANDING, IRAQ, OFFICER COMMA^ING, GTJLF STATIONS, ROYAL AIR FORCE. (Cn^y Ttia Cownan<le!V*ln*Chief, East Indies.) Captain P. Skalton, Royal Navy will >»e to Parlor Naval Offlcar*, Poralan Gulf *y Captain A.R. 'alUs, Royal Navy on 23 rd August, I 960 . CAPTAIN, SENIOR NAVAL OFFICER, PERSIAN GULF.Aide Meaoire, Since the oonstituticaial changes in India the Naval Connander in Chief East Indies is no longer styled * Kis Excellency ', and receives a salute of 15 guns only* fir/lZj n.rt. h f^ i2j C I'uLj T ■B9/8/50 (S') BRITISH RESIDENCY, X BAHRAIN. 23rd February, 1950. I have read with interest the report contained in your letter 18/9/1-A/50 of the 6th February on the recent visit of the Commander-in-Chief, East Indies to Muscat. I am sorry the Sultan proved so difficult. I have not received any complaints from the Navy, and, unless I do so, do not propose to pass on your letter to any other authority, but will mention the visit briefly in my monthly letter. 2. There is one small point to which I would call attention, that in the old days v the Commander-in-Chief, x^ast Indies was an Excellency ana used to receive a salute of 17 guns in Indian waters including the Gulf. Now that he no longer belongs to the Indian hierarchy and that the Gulf waters are no longer regarded as Indian he is no£an 'Excellency' 1 and entitled only to a Vice- iidmiral* s salute of 15 guns. I would suggest that you might mention this to the Sultan at?• Programme of Commander-In-Chief's visit to ^scat, 7? 2l 8.30 a.m. H.M.S, Mauritius arrived and saluted country - shore battery replied* 9.30 a.au Consul called on C-in-C. IO .15 a.m. C-in-C left and landed at Consulate. Shore battery saluted as C-in-C passed ifarami Fort* 21 guns. II guns. P.A. eas in | plain clothes but salute f was fired {vf courtesy. 5 17 duns 5 by J Motor beats the Navy, 10.45 a.n. C-in-C and Captain of Mauritius called on Sultan. Accompanied by H.M's Consul. 11*45 a.m. Sultan returned call on H.M.S. Mauritius. 5 21 Guns when Sultan left • f 12.30 p.m. Calls on C-in-C and Mauritius by Male meafoers of British Colony In Wardroom (Launch Anne) 1.30 p.m. Lunch at Consulate for (Sultan and]C-in-C. Sultan after agreeing to draft programme, later refused this invitation. 4*15 ?.»• Hockey Match - Mauritius Vs Exiles/Maqbul Clubs (Draw). J M.30 p.m. Supper and Cinema on board for Colony. 4th Feburary. 1030 a.m. Visitors on board 1130 a.m. - do - Launch Anne took children accompanied by parents and 50 school children. Adults ( own arrangements )• I.15 p.m. C-in-C 1 s lunch party for Sultan. ( motor boats by Navy ). 2.0 p.m. Launch Anne took 25 nr 30 sailors to Sahraali beach. Party of 15 sailors saw over Marani Fort. Dragoman ds guide• 1 4*15 p.m. Hockey match Mauritius Vs Muscat Infantry ( Prevented by rain ) 6.30 p.m. to 8. $ p.m. At Home at Consulate. ( Land Khor Jett^y Boats by Navy Cars by Consulate.) 6.30 p.m. Cinema on board for party of about 20 or 30 Indian* and Arabs, and 30 school children tnd teachers. Launch Anne. 5th F.buarr • 9• 0 a «m» Shooting Match Mauritius VS Muscat Infantry. Transport by Muscat Infantry. ( Mauritius won easily ). 2. 0 p.m. Mauritius departed. VCTh« PritlBh Conaulett#. ;i(>SCAT . 6 th Fabuary, 1950. CoBaaftnciT-ln-Chlef i&gt Inrilea vi sit to ^locat. Ity dear Sir Rupert, I ancloaa a copy of tha programme observed at ruacr.t on th* occasion of the visit of h.M.S. %uritiua from the 'jrd to the 5th Febuary. The progranae itself went off very well, though ot tinea the weather was threatening and we had aone rain. I was informed by Koods-Ballerd to whom I sent suggestions for the visit in the shape of e draft prcgramne, that the Sultan had approved all cay suggestions, and so got the progranae finalised and confirtaed by the C orcnander-in-Chief, r On the evening of the 1st Febuary Woods-Ballard told ae that the Sultan was leaving for Sur hy launch on the afternoon of the 3rd Febuary. I pointed out at once that it struck me as very ungracious that after the whole progranm had been arranged, and the ship had come all this way to visit Muscat, the Sultan should not even wait fur the Coeraander-in-Chief*e lunch on the 4 th I ebT aryjwhich he had virtually acc pted. I offered to cancel nine on the 3rd, ar*f have the Coafnander-in-Chief'a then. However ->ods-Ballard at ray request then telephoned the Sultan, and h* decided to stay over till the evening of the 4 th. Next day on getting the approval of the Cosriander-in-Chief to the progranme, I issued ay own luncheon invitations, thereupon I got a letter from the Sultan to say that he could not cone, and his Minister for Foreign Affaire would explain. This Woods-Ballard did, to the effect that the Sultan objected to coaing because there was no precedent. I certainly could find no actual precedent, but of course he comes when the Polit cal Resident visits. He also case when I asked hia before when the Senior Naval Officer visited Just after ny arrival here. However I did not see any point in taking up the question of precedent, and merely said that it was not an official function but a private party, and that if the Sultan did not wish to come, there was no more to be said. I cannot help feeling that Woods-Ballard forgot tc show the Sultan my draft programme in the first place, so I wrote a letter to the Sultan, simply thanking him for his letter and apologising for having bothered him with my invitation, and saying that I would never have written it, had I not been given to understand that he had had the suggested programme laid before him and approved it and trusted the rest of the programme was satisfactory. I enclose copies of our letters for your information. I met the Sultan at the call and at the Cooiaander-5n-Chief *s lunch, and he seemed quite as friendly as ever, but made no mention of the subject, so I did not raise it either. I think, as over sending the launch for your departure, someone had tripped up, b t they^e not telling. I see Saiyid Thuwainy is working as a sort of private secretary in the Palace, and it is possible he is making mistakes, or forgetting to put things up that I?nods-Ballard refers through him. Only yesterday when I sent some sailors to see the Fort the Police said t ey had had no Instructions, though Salyid Thuwainy had assured us that they had. Anyhow I am sure it is not the Sultan, who never forgets aiything, and aeeraa invariably co-operative and friendly whenever we meet. The only real disappointment of the v&slt was when the Marines volunteered to play Retreat on the hockey field after the match. Though Salyld Tariq and Woods-Ballard had welcomed it provisionally, and it was all laid on, when they His Excellency Sir Rupert Hay. K.C.I.E.,C.S.I. Political Resident. BAHRAIN.mam (32J - 2 - th«y put it to the Suit*n f he fimly nepatived the whole l ea. lo reaeon waa divert• I aug ©sted it wa a *a4t too near prayer t-j^e and wr let that get about, as the itevy were rather hur* f except tne Coauapdea -In-Chief who oonaidered it was entirely up to the Sultan and :;o one had ar$r right to criticiee )• T*oode-Ballard seems to think the Sultan's main reason was just a feeling that, it would be too nuch demonstration by our Navy. It certainly would have offered the very greatest attraction the local people have perhaps ever had, and there was keen disappointment• Youra sincerely. Sd/ F.C.L. [27 PERSIAN GULF RESIDENCY, BAHRAIN. I6th December, 1949 Please refer to your savingram No. 18 November, 29$h. 3. The Commander in Chief ^ast Indies is His Excellency Vic« Admiral Sir Charles H. L. Woodhouse, K.C.B.^Royal Navy and he will be accompanied by his wife Lady Woodhouse and daughter Miss Woodhouse• 3. The ship is the 'Mauritius' commanded by Captain. T. J. Hil&en, D.S.O. Major. F. C. L. Chauncy, Political Agent, MUSCAT.*2/9/1-a/50 The British Consulate fMUSCAT . 22nd J^mraary, 1950 Visit of Coryifander-ln-Chjef . My dear Woods-Ballard, Please refer to my letter No. I7/9/I-A/49 datec H - 12 - *49. I have now been informed that Lady Woodhouse and ^iss Woodhouse wi.ll be in ’feuritius for the Commander- -in-Chieffs cruise. Will you kinily inform the Sultan. Yours sincerely, His ’fejesty’s Consul, Muscat B. Woods-Ballard, Esq. C.I.E.,M.B.E Minister for Foreign Affairs, MUSCATOFFICE OF THE SENIOR NAVAL OFFICER, PERSIAN GULF. 2nd January ^ 9^0. N*. P.G. 15/1 3?A9/E. Here fire the invitation cards sent in accordance with Senior Navel Officer, Persian Gulf's signal timed 3011 30Z/t) e broker. As T have not had the opportunity of discussing with you the details for this year’s visit of Commander-in-Chief, East Indies to ?4uscat, I have assumed last year’s plan will in general be suitable; It has been followed fairly closely for his visits to other places. 2. I enclose a copy of the flagship’s cruise programme and a list of officers embarked in her. It will, I am sure, be of great help to Commander-in-Chief’s staff and the ship’s officers if you are able to forward to the Flag Lieutenant, before arrival, a list of people invited on Commander-in-Chief's and the ship’s behalf^ to the various functions onboard; but this may not be possible if air communications dohfet fit in. 3. Senior Nav^JL Officer, Persian Gulf, intends at present, to accompany^tiommander-in-Chief on his cruise as far as Basra only, and to return to Bahrein about 2 c th January. With all good wisnes for the New Year. Major F .L. Mauritius arrives and salutes country - shore batter^* replies 21 guns. 9-30 a.m. H.M*s Consul calls on C.-in-C. 10-15 a.m. <****(£- / . / A / Q C.-in-C. will^land at the Consulate,Shore Battery salutes 17 guns as C.-in-C. passes Marani Fort. 10-45 a.m. C.-in-C. and Captain of Mauritius Accompanied call on Sultan by H.M's. Consul. 11-45 a.m. Sultan returns call on H.M.S. 21 guns when Mautitius. Sultan leaves. 12-^6 p.m. Ca}ls by Male members of British European Colony. In Wardroom. 1)0 l-i£ p.m. Lunch at Consulate for Sultan and C.-in-C. 2 p.m. Launch Anne can take party of 25 or 30 sailors to SahmalA beach. PartlAr of 15 sailors can see over Marani Fort? 4-15 p.m. Hockey Match Mauritius Vs.Exiles Maobool Club. 7-30 p.m. Supper and Cinema on board ftSDXfk for Colony. 4TH FEBRUARY. - 10-30 i.'m;* Visitors on board Children accompanied by parents. 11-30 a.m. Adults. 1-15 p.m. C.in-C^s lunch party for, Sultan. 2 p.m. Launch Anne available for taking 25 or 30 sailors to Sahmala beach. Parti|^ of 15 sailors can see over Marani FortQ 4-15 p.m. Hockey match Mauritius Vs. Muscat Infantry. 6-30 p.m. 6-30 p.m. At Home at Consulate. Cinema on board for party of about 20 or 30 Indians and Arabs. 5TH FEBRUARY 9 a.m. Shooting Match Vs. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: 'File 9/1 A III Visit of Commander-in-Chief to Muscat'

physicalDescription.extent: The file is arranged in chronological order from the rear to the front.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 55, these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.A previous foliation sequence, which is also circled, has been superseded and therefore crossed out.

mods.abstract: Correspondence and other papers relating to visits by the Commander-in-Chief, East Indies Station, to Muscat. The file covers a visit in early 1950 and a proposed visit in early 1951 which was later cancelled. The papers deal with matters such as notifying the Sultan of Muscat, the programme of events for the visits, lists of officers aboard visiting ships, and appropriate gun salutes. A proposed visit in May 1950 of the Senior Naval Officer in the Persian Gulf, Bahrain, is also discussed. Vessels mentioned in the file include HMS Wild Gooseand Mauritius. A report on the Commander-in-Chief's visit by Major Frederick Charles Leslie Chauncy, Political Agent and Consul, Muscat, 6 February 1950, is included in the file (folio 31).Correspondence comes from: the Senior Naval Officer in the Persian Gulf, Bahrain; the Political Agency, Muscat; the Persian Gulf Residency, Bahrain; Said bin Taimur [Sa‘īd ibn Taymūr Āl Bū Sa‘īd], Sultan of Muscat; and Basil Woods Ballard, Minister for Foreign Affairs, Muscat.

name.namePart: Royal Navy, Commander-in-Chief, East Indies Station
Sultan of Muscat and Oman, Āl Bū Sa'īd Dynasty
